Diethyl pentane-1,5-diyldicarbamate (PDC), a bio-based intermediate used for isocyanate and polyurethanes, was synthesized by the direct carbonylation of CO2 and pentanediamine (PDA) with 2-cyanopyridine (2-CP) over Zr-doped CeO2. In this study, Zr-doped CeO2 catalysts with different contents of Zr are successfully synthesized to produce PDC from PDA, CO2, and ethanol. Among them, Zr0.05Ce exhibits enhanced reaction activity and the productivity reached 6.0 mmol·g−1·h−1. Characterizations based on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Raman, and CO2/NH3-temperature-programmed desorption prove that the doping of Zr atoms into CeO2 regulates the acid–base sites and promotes oxygen vacancy formation, which is primarily responsible for the formation of monoethyl carbonate, an intermediate for diethyl carbonate (DEC). In-situ diffuse reflectance Fourier-transform spectrometry and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy reveal that PDA reacts with 2-CP to form N, N'-(pentane-1,5-diyl)dipicolinamide, which are transformed into PDC. Finally, the catalytic activity could be regenerated after calcination. This study presents a green route for producing bio-based carbamate by constructing C-N bond using CO2 as a carbonyl source, which can replace carbamates derived from petrochemical resources in the future. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Key words Bio-based carbamate Carbon dioxide Doped CeO2 Carbonylation Polyurethane precursor Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Dicarbamate, as an environmentally benign compound and intermediate for the synthesis of isocyanates and polyurethanes, has broad applications in many fields, such as wind blade, automobile, and adhesives industry [1–5]. The synthesis of dicarbamates has been extensively studied because they can replace extremely toxic phosgene in the production of isocyanates [5–7]. Up to now, a series of dicarbamates has been developed, including dimethyl hexane-1,6-diyldicarbamate (HDC), 4,4′-methylenediphenyl dicarbamate, toluene dicarbamate, and diethyl (1,4-phenylenebis(methylene))dicarbamate [8,9]. Except for these dicarbamates, PDC, as an emerging bio-based dicarbamate, has triggered wide interest because its starting material, PDA, is derived from biomass instead of a traditional nonrenewable petrochemical resource [10]. PDA has been industrially produced through biological fermentation. Further, the PDC synthesized in this study is used to produce pentamethylene diisocyanate, thus, 100% renewable carbon is used [11,12]. To date, reports on the synthesis of PDC from PDA are scarce [13]. Significant efforts have been made to obtain other dicarbamates by an efficient and green method, including the carbonylation of amines with carbamates, carbonates, urea, and CO2 [2,14-17]. In recent years, the utilization of CO2 to synthesize carbamates has been increasingly emphasized [18–22]. However, water produced in the reaction strongly results in equilibrium limitations, leading to low conversion and yield. To overcome this problem, Deng's research group successfully synthesized HDC from CO2 in two steps. First, polyurea was prepared from CO2 and diamines; thereafter, they were transformed into corresponding dicarbamates via degradation with urea [23,24]. The direct production of dicarbamates with the catalytic hydration of nitriles is an effective method of overcoming the equilibrium limitation. Further, 2-cyanopyridine (2-CP) shows excellent performance in such a carbonylation reaction for carbamates from aliphatic amines, CO2, and alcohol. Keiichi et al. reported that a high yield of methyl N-phenyl carbamate was obtained from CO2, aniline, and methanol catalyzed by CeO2 with 2-CP. In this process, water was in situ removed by the reaction with 2-CP to afford 2-picolinamide (2-PA) [25]. The resulting 2-PA could reform 2-CP through dehydration catalyzed by Na2O/SiO2 and be used to produce niacin [26,27]. CeO2 exhibits excellent performance in the transformation of CO2 due to its abundant acid-base sites and oxygen vacancy. Meng et al. have revealed that CeO2 with different morphologies exhibits different physicochemical properties, which influence the catalytic activity in HDC synthesis from 1,6-hexanediamine (HDA), CO2, and methanol. The activity of CeO2 catalysts highly depends on the surface properties, such as acid–base sites, surface area, and oxygen vacancies [2]. Stefan et al. studied the role of different metal-doped ceria catalysts in the synthesis of methyl N-phenylcarbamate from anilines and CO2. They proposed that oxygen vacancies formed by doping metal are important in the generation of carbamates [28]. Goula et al. proposed that incorporating Pr3+ or Sm3+ into the lattice of cerium oxide not only improves Lewis basic positions and oxygen vacancy sites but also improve the stability of the catalyst by preventing the aggregation of the active sites [29]. Furthermore, they successfully synthesized La doped-Ceria catalysts used for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, in which lattice oxygen vacancies were formed facilitating the chemisorption and dissociation of CO2 [30]. Hence, the reaction performance has been hindered due to the equilibrium limitation and moderate activity of the CeO2 catalyst although significant efforts have been made in the synthesis of carbamates. More importantly, the reaction mechanism and pathway are needed to be elucidated based on prior studies, particularly in the presence of 2-CP. Therefore, herein, we report the one-step catalytic carbonylation of PDA with CO2 and ethanol to produce PDC over Zr-doped CeO2 catalysts and 2-CP. Highly active CeO2 catalysts have been developed by doping with different contents of Zr to change their physicochemical properties. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were characterized by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2-physisorption, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The influence of doping content on the catalytic activity was investigated. Subsequently, the influences of reaction conditions, e.g., the reaction temperature, CO2 pressure, molar ratio of the reactant, and reaction time, on the PDC yields are examined. Additionally, the reaction mechanism was investigated through in situ Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) and diffuse reflectance Fourier-transform spectrometry (DRIFTS) characterization. Finally, the recyclability of the catalysts was examined. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation A pure CeO2 catalyst was prepared by precipitation. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was completely dissolved in deionized water. Thereafter, a NaOH solution was dropped under stirring at room temperature. The resulting suspended solid was filtered, cleaned with deionized water, dried overnight at 100°C, and calcined at 550°C for 5 h. The metal-doped CeO2 catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation. Metal nitrate and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O were mixed at different ratios (based on the molar ratio of the metal) and completely dissolved in deionized water. Meanwhile, NaOH solution was prepared by dissolving 7 g of NaOH in 200 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, the NaOH solution was added dropwise to the above metal solutions with vigorous stirring. The mixture was continuously stirred for another 5 h. After that, the precipitate was separated by centrifugation, washed with deionized water to neutralize it, and dried overnight at 100°C. The resulting solid catalyst was calcined at 550°C for 5 h. The catalysts were denoted as MxCe, where x represents the molar ratio of the metal in the catalyst, i.e., M/(M+Ce) [31,32]. 2.2 Catalytic performance evaluation PDC synthesis was carried out in a 50 mL autoclave reactor under continuous magnetic stirring. Further, 0.15 g of the catalyst, 2.5 mmol PDA, 40 mmol 2-CP, and 200 mmol ethanol were added into an autoclave. The catalyst was not treated again under a flow of industrial air or oxygen before catalytic evaluation. Thereafter, the reactor was sealed and purged with CO2 at 3 MPa. The reactor was heated to the desired temperature for 4 h. The reaction liquid was taken out and centrifuged to remove the catalyst. The liquid was analyzed quantitatively by chromatography and qualitatively by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS). 2.3 Material characterization Powder XRD patterns were obtained using a Bruker D8 diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source; conditions: tube voltage: 40 kV, tube current: 40 mA, scanning speed: 6° min−1, and scanning range: 5°–90°. Specific areas were measured by N2 adsorption–desorption using the Quantachrome Autosorb−1 adsorption instrument. The samples were pretreated at 300°C for 5 h to remove impurities. The specific surface area was calculated by the BET method, and pore volume and diameter were obtained based on the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda method. Raman spectra were recorded on a HORIBA scientific LabRAM HR Evolution equipped with a charged device detector using He/Ne laser with a wavelength of 514 nm. The XPS data were collected on an ultrahigh vacuum ESCALAB 250Xi using Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) with binding energies referenced to the C1s peak at 284.8 eV. The concentrations of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies were calculated based on Eq. (1–4). A is the area of the corresponding peaks. (1) C [ C e 3 + ] = A C e 3 + / ( A C e 3 + + A C e 4 + ) (2) A C e 3 + = A V 1 + A V 2 + A V 3 + A V 4 (3) A C e 4 + = A U 1 + A U 2 + A U 3 + A U 4 + A U 5 + A U 6 (4) C [ O V ] = A O V / ( A O L + A O V + A O C ) The TPD of NH3 and CO2 was studied on a ChemBET Pulsar TPR/TPD. The temperature program was as follows: 200 mg of catalyst was purged with He at 100 mL min−1 for 20 min, the temperature was increased to 200°C at 10°C min−1, and the impurities adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst was removed after 60 min. Afterward, the temperature was reduced to 50°C, and we waited for 30 min. Thereafter, 10 vol% of NH3 or CO2/He flowed through the catalysts, and we waited for 30 min, and the signal was collected using a thermal conductivity detector. All infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Mettler-Toledo ReactIR 15 equipped with a high-pressure probe. The IR spectra were collected every 30 s and analyzed using the IC IR software. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Prepared Material The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . The isotherms of all catalysts are classified as type IV with an H2 hysteresis loop, suggesting that the catalysts have mesoporous structures [33]. Notably, the pore size distribution of all catalysts was 2–10 nm, and the average pore size decreased from 5.6 to 4.0 nm with the increasing content of Zr. Further, the Zr0.05Ce displayed a bimodal pore size distribution with the pore size mainly centered at 4 and 8 nm. The specific surface areas of the catalysts are summarized in Fig. 1(a). The surface areas of these catalysts decreased in the following order: Zr0.075Ce > Zr0.1Ce > Zr0.025Ce > Zr0.05Ce > CeO2. These phenomena indicate that the doping of Zr into CeO2 can slightly change the surface areas and pore sizes. The morphology of the CeO2 and ZrxCe catalysts was investigated by SEM, TEM, and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), and the images are shown in Fig.S1 and Fig. 2 , respectively. CeO2 exhibited irregular morphology with particle sizes varying from 10 to 20 nm. Similarly, The ZrxCe catalysts had an irregular morphology, suggesting that the small doping of Zr into CeO2 had a small effect on the morphology of CeO2. Further, the TEM images of all catalysts showed that the dominating lattice spacing was 0.32 nm, which was consistent with the (111) planes of ceria and the previous report [34–37]. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of CeO2, ZrO2, and Zr-doped CeO2 catalysts. The diffraction peaks of pure CeO2 at 28.5°, 33.2°, 47.6°, and 59.2° were ascribed to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes, respectively, which were significantly indexed to the cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 (JCPDS 04-0593) [38]. Notably, Zr-doped catalysts showed the same characteristic peaks as pure CeO2, and the peaks belonging to ZrO2 were not observed, indicating that Zr was successfully incorporated into the ceria lattice structure and fluorite solid solutions were created. Interestingly, the peak position of the above planes in the Zr- doped CeO2 catalyst slightly shifted to the high-angle side with the increase in the Zr doping content. A similar trend was observed by Dai et al. and Li et al. [31,34]. The lattice parameters were calculated and are listed in Table S1. The interplanar spacing (Å) values for five catalysts were 3.13, 3.12, 3.11, 3.11, and 3.10, which decreased with increasing Zr doping content. This was due to the replacement of Ce4+ by Zr4+ because the ion radius of Ce4+ (0.97 Å) was larger than that of Zr4+ (0.84 Å), resulting in the shrinking interplanar spacing, hence, the characteristic peaks of CeO2 move to a high angle [34,35,39]. Additionally, these phenomena confirmed the incorporation of Zr4+ into the lattice of CeO2. Raman spectroscopy is frequently conducted to provide information on the structure, defects, and particle sizes of the catalysts [31,40–42]. Fig. 4 shows the Raman spectra of the pure CeO2 and ZrxCe catalysts. The band located at 463.7 cm−1 was assigned to the symmetrical stretching F2g mode of the CeO2 catalysts. Notably, a red shift in the peaks was observed, and with the increase in the Zr content, the F2g band shifted to 465.3, 466.3, 466.7, and 467.7 cm−1 for Zr0.025Ce, Zr0.05Ce, Zr0.075Ce, and Zr0.1Ce, respectively. This was because the length of the Ce–O band gradually decreased with increasing Zr doping content, leading to a shift to relatively high energy in the Raman spectra. This phenomenon further confirmed that Zr cooperated with Ce to form solid solutions. The weak band located at approximately 598 cm−1 corresponded with the defect-induced D mode, which is ascribed to the oxygen vacancies due to the Ce3+. It has been reported that doping Zr into the CeO2 catalysts easily results in the production of more oxygen vacancies owing to the generation of Ce3+ in the catalysts. Generally, the D band was normalized to the F2g band, which was used to indicate the concentration of the oxygen vacancy. The ID/IF2g values of the pure CeO2 and Zr-doped CeO2 catalysts were in the order of Zr0.05Ce > Zr0.025Ce > Zr0.1Ce > Zr0.075Ce > CeO2. The XPS spectra were adopted to further investigate the chemical state of the Ce and O elements, as shown in Fig. 5 . It shows the Ce 3d spectra of the CeO2 and Zr-doped CeO2 catalysts and their corresponding deconvolution peaks. The Ce 3d spectra could be decomposed into ten peaks: U1 (∼882.27 eV), U2 (∼888.68 eV), U3 (∼898.34 eV), U4 (∼900.787 eV), U5 (∼907.33 eV), U6 (∼916.66 eV), V1 (∼880.20 eV), V2 (∼884.64 eV), V3 (∼897.07 eV), and V4 (∼903.32eV). The six U peaks were assigned to Ce4+, and the other four V peaks were ascribed to Ce3+. The 3d5/2 spin-obit component was labeled as V1, U1, V2, U2, and U3. V3, U4, V4, U5, and U6 referred to the 3d3/2 spin-obit component. The calculated concentrations of Ce3+ are 38.4%, 39.7%, 47.0%, 42.0%, and 41.3% for CeO2, Zr0.025Ce, Zr0.05Ce, Zr0.075Ce, and Zr0.1Ce, respectively. The concentration of Ce3+ decreased in the order of Zr0.05Ce > Zr0.025Ce > Zr0.1Ce > Zr0.075Ce > CeO2, indicating that the concentration of the oxygen vacancies follows the same trend as the Raman results. Moreover, the Zr-doped CeO2 possesses more Ce3+ than pure CeO2, confirming that doping with Zr can increase the amount of Ce3+. Generally, the generation of Ce3+ is associated with oxygen vacancies, which are beneficial for the catalytic activity in the carbonylation reaction of PDA and CO2. Therefore, the concentration of Ce3+ can represent the concentration of oxygen vacancies. Zr0.05Ce has the highest concentration of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies. Fig. 5b depicts the O1s spectra of the catalysts, which showed three peaks at 529.2, 531.1, and 532.7 eV. These peaks were ascribed to lattice oxygen (OL), oxygen in the form of O2−/O− adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies (OV), and chemisorbed oxygen species (OC). The oxygen vacancy concentrations of catalysts were 25%, 26%, 30%, 29%, and 27% for CeO2, Zr0.025Ce, Zr0.05Ce, Zr0.075Ce, and Zr0.1Ce, respectively. Notably, the results were consistent with those from the Raman spectra and XPS spectra of Ce 3d, suggesting that doping Zr into CeO2 catalysts promoted the generation of OV, and Zr0.05Ce possessed the highest concentration of OV. The CO2 uptakes of the catalysts were estimated from the results of CO2–TPD shown in Table S1. It can be seen from Fig. 6 , the desorption peaks of CO2 were located in the range of 50°C–200°C and 200°C–400°C, which could be ascribed to the weak and medium basic sites for the catalysts, respectively. Generally, the weak basic sites are derived from metal–oxygen pairs, and the moderate basic sites are due to unsaturated oxygen atoms. The position of the desorption peaks of the catalysts varied with different contents of Zr. The desorption temperature of Zr0.075Ce was the highest, suggesting the strong interaction between CO2 and Zr0.075Ce. From the CO2 desorption area, it was found that the amount of CO2 desorbed followed the order Zr0.075Ce > Zr0.025Ce > Zr0.05 > CeO2 > Zr0.1Ce. Notably, the amounts of the desorbed CO2 determined from CO2–TPD were not proportional to the specific surface areas. It was reported that OV could promote the adsorption of CO2, affording CO2-derived species. It is noted that Zr0.05Ce showed a higher concentration of oxygen vacancy than Zr0.075Ce but lower CO2 uptake. Yu et al. proposed that not all OV were present on the surface of the catalyst to aid CO2 adsorption. Further, CO2 adsorption was influenced by the exposed facets and atomic orientations [43]. Overall, the trend of the Ov concentration is inconsistent with that of the amount of adsorbed CO2. The investigation of acidic sites was carried out by NH3–TPD. NH3 desorption (Fig.S2) occurred in the range of 100°C–300°C, 300°C–500°C, and 500°C–600°C, which could be ascribed to weak, medium, and strong adsorption, respectively. Notably, the desorption temperatures of Zr0.05Ce were the highest, suggesting that the interaction of NH3 with Zr0.05Ce was stronger than that of other catalysts. The NH3 uptake was estimated from the NH3 desorption area and followed the order Zr0.05Ce > Zr0.1Ce > Zr0.075Ce > Zr0.025Ce > CeO2. It was emphasized that the number of the total basic sites of the Zr-doped CeO2 was higher than that of CeO2, which indicated that the addition of Zr improved the basic sites of the CeO2 catalyst. 3.2 Effects of the catalysts and 2-CP Water is the only byproduct of the carbonylation of PDA, CO2, and ethanol to afford PDC. Excessive water leads to low PDA conversion and PDC yield because of equilibrium limitations. The great role of dehydrating agents to overcome equilibrium limitations for the synthesis of carbamates was confirmed by Sakakura, and Tomishige et al. To further validate the progress of the reaction between PDA and CO2 in ethanol without any dehydrating agent, only the CeO2 catalyst was introduced into the reaction system. It can be seen that in Fig. 7 , PDA conversion significantly increased, and approximately 10% PDC yield was achieved, which is slightly better than that in a blank test (7% PDA conversion). According to a report from Tomishige [44], 2-CP could overcome the severe equilibrium limitation with the in situ removal of water catalyzed by CeO2. Therefore, CeO2 and 2-CP were introduced into the reaction system simultaneously, the PDC yield was 6.7 times higher than that when CeO2 was used alone. It was proven that the combination of CeO2 and 2-CP promoted the highly efficient conversion of PDA and improve the yield of PDC. It was reported that about 80% yield of 1,6-dimethyl hexane-1,6-diyldicarbamate (HDC) from CO2, methanol, and diamine over CeO2 catalysts was achieved in the absence of a dehydrating agent [2]. Although a high yield of HDC was obtained in a similar reaction system, catalytic performance for the synthesis of PDC from PDA, CO2, and methanol was compared with that of HDC to further proved the essential role of CeO2 and 2-CP. The PDA conversion and PDC yield are 94.8% and 3.9% (not shown here), indicating that it is hard to produce in the same method. Besides, alcohol act as both reactant and solvent in our system, hence, avoiding the introduction of other solvents, such as 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone. Surprisingly, when 2-CP was added individually, high PDA conversion was achieved and PDC was not generated, which is due to the interaction between PDA and 2-CP to form byproducts or intermediates. In conclusion, the combination of CeO2 and 2-CP is essential for the production of PDC. 3.3 Catalytic performance It is reported that CeO2 possesses both acidic and basic sites, which could be adjusted by doping different types of metals. Hence, the influence of different metals doped into CeO2 on the PDC yields was examined during the PDC synthesis. Fig. S3 depicts the PDA conversion and PDC yield over different metal-doped CeO2 catalysts. The conversions of PDA were approximately 100% for all catalysts because of the CeO2 and 2-CP. Remarkably, except for Al-doped CeO2, the catalytic performance of the other metal-doped catalysts was superior to that of CeO2, which strongly proved that the surface modification of CeO2 by metal doping could promote the formation of PDC. Additionally, among these catalysts, the Zr-doped CeO2 exhibited better catalytic activity due to more acidic or basic sites, receiving 100% PDA conversion and 65% PDC yield, which is ascribed to its smaller ionic radius than Ce4+ [45]. Based on the above results, to investigate the catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts, the different amounts of Zr doped into CeO2 on the catalytic performance was investigated. As seen in Fig. 8 , a maximum yield (38%) of PDC was obtained for Zr0.05Ce. Zr0.025Ce displayed inferior catalytic performance (30% yield), which is similar to that of the pure CeO2 catalysts (29% yield). Further increasing the contents of Zr decreased the PDC yields, which were 19% and 18% for Zr0.075Ce and Zr0.1Ce, respectively. Therefore, Zr0.05Ce was chosen as the catalyst for the subsequent reactions. The surface oxygen vacancy associated with Ce3+ on the catalyst surface could behave as active sites that encourage CO2 adsorption and activation. The Raman and XPS results showed that the doping of Zr could alter the concentration of Ce3+ in CeO2. Fig. S4 shows that the oxygen vacancy concentration shows a similar varying tendency to the performance of the catalysts. According to several experimental and theoretical studies, it was proven that CO2 was transformed into a CO2 − intermediate by inserting one of the O atoms into the OV [46]. Hence, the existence of oxygen vacancy is beneficial for the catalytic activity. However, the trend of performance varying with the Zr doping content is not completely the same as that of oxygen concentration. This indicates that except for the activation of CO2 over oxygen vacancy, acid–base sites are desired, which contribute to the adsorption of amine and ethanol. Further, the basic and acidic sites play key roles in the synthesis of PDC. The CO2 uptake is calculated from the TPD peak area mentioned above. As can be seen, the CO2 uptake of the catalysts is not proportional to the oxygen vacancy concentration and PDC yields, indicating that the basic site is not the major factor. Additionally, the acidic sites of Zr0.05Ce were larger than those of other catalysts from the NH3–TPD results, which suggested that improved acidity plays a crucial role in PDA adsorption. Hence, optimum acidity, good basicity, and OV are required to prepare the PDC. The influence of reaction time on the yields of PDC over Zr0.05Ce was investigated and is shown in Fig. 9 a. Interestingly, the PDA conversion reached 100% at the beginning, which indicates that PDA was completely converted within 2 h. This was because the addition of 2-CP could promote the conversion of PDA. As expected, the PDC yields significantly increased at the beginning of the reaction and continued to slowly increase with prolonged reaction time. It is noted that the amount of DEC reduced with prolonging reaction time.This is because the PDC was quickly formed from the DEC with intermediate derived from PDA with sufficient 2-CP. However, the equilibrium limitation affects the PDC yield when the 2-CP was depleted. Further, some amine-based by-products were generated during the reaction, resulting in a low PDC yield. As mentioned, the addition of 2-CP plays a crucial role in the production of PDC, and the influence of the 2-CP amount on the PDC yields was studied, as shown in Fig. 9b. The increasing amount of 2-CP from 5 to 30 mmol afforded a relatively high PDC yield, and it reached a peak value at 30 mmol. Besides, when the amount of 2-CP increased, the amount of DEC showed an upward trend. During the reaction, 2-CP was employed as a dehydrant to remove water and facilitate the equilibrium shifting toward the formation of DEC, which is an intermediate in the production of PDC. Relatively large amounts of 2-CP are beneficial for the formation of DEC, thereby improving the yield of PDC. Furthermore, 2-PA, by the reaction of 2-CP and water, reacted with PDA to form the intermediate, which was transformed into PDC. Therefore, 30 mmol 2-CP is beneficial for the production of PDC. Fig. S5 shows the effect of the amount of ethanol on the PDC yields. Notably, the PDC yield rapidly increased and reached a plateau at nethanol/nPDA = 200, which was 62.9%. With the further increase in the ethanol content, the PDC yields slightly decreased, suggesting that excess ethanol was not suitable to improve the PDC yield. This was because ethanol acted as a solution and was involved in the synthesis of PDC. Hence, appropriately improving the amount of ethanol is beneficial for the high yield of PDC; however, too much ethanol dilutes the concentration of the catalyst, resulting in a decline in catalytic efficiency. Hence, 80:1 of ethanol/PDA is the optimal ratio. Additionally, the effect of CO2 pressure on the PDC yields was investigated and is illustrated in Fig. 9c. Interestingly, the PDC yield shows a downward trend with increasing pressure and reaches a minimum value (57.7%) at 3 MPa. However, the PDC yield increased when the initial CO2 pressure increased to 5 MPa. A similar result was obtained by Meng et al. [2]. They studied the influence of CO2 pressure on the synthesis of HDC without 2-CP. It was found that the conversion of HDA increased with increasing pressure. The selectivity slightly reduced at first and gradually increased when the pressure increased to 5 MPa. When the initial pressure was low, the reaction occurred in the gas phase. The mass transfer rate in the gas phase was advantageous for the reaction. Nevertheless, increasing CO2 pressure leads to the development of supercritical CO2 at 190°C, which enhances CO2 conversion and affords high PDC yield. The effect of reaction temperature on the reaction outcome is described in Fig. 9d. The PDC yield increased from 46.6% to 75.7% when the reaction temperature increased from 170°C to 190°C. At relatively high temperatures, 62.6% of the PDC yield was obtained, which may be caused by the temperature dependence of the reaction equilibrium and the enhanced side reaction of PDA. Therefore, 190°C is the appropriate reaction temperature. 3.4 Study of the reaction pathway between PDA, CO2, and ethanol Clarifying the reaction path for the synthesis of PDC from CO2 is important to guide the improvement of the PDC yield. A series of experiments is performed to investigate the role of these components in the formation of PDC. As can be seen in Table 1 , 1.6 mmol of PDC and 15.8 mmol of DEC are produced with 100% PDA conversion (entry 1). Several by-products or intermediates are identified as ethyl carbamate, DEC, 2-PA, ethyl picolinate, and ethyl (5-aminopentyl)carbamate, as shown in Fig. S6. Additionally, DEC and PDC were not detected in the absence of 2-CP (entry 2), suggesting that ethanol was essential and could promote the formation of PDC and DEC. Furthermore, Urakawa et al. have confirmed that carbonate is produced at a high yield (>90%) from CO2 and methanol over the CeO2 catalyst, promoted by 2-CP [47]. Hence, DEC is a potential intermediate in the formation of PDC from PDA, CO2, and ethanol. In contrast, CO2 was replaced with DEC (entry 3), and 0.75 mmol PDC was produced, proving that DEC could act as an intermediate for PDC production. The reaction equations were summarized as follows (Scheme 1 ). Furthermore, the conversion of PDA in entry 1 and entry 2 was approximately 100%. However, the yields of PDC were significantly lower than the theoretical value. It indicates that PDA was converted into an unknown intermediate that was not detected by GC–MS. Hence, the reaction liquid from entry 1 was detected by MS, and the result is shown in Fig. S7. Notably, the main component was detected as N, N'-(pentane-1,5-diyl)dipicolinamide, which was formed by PDA and picolinamide. Similarly, Satsuma et al. reported that 2-CP reacted with amines to form N-alkyl amides catalyzed by the CeO2 catalyst [46]. Entries 5–8 were carried out to further determine this reaction. It was found that PDA was completely converted without CO2 and catalyst (entry 5). Additionally, it proved that the reaction of PDA/2-CP adduct with DEC can not occur without the catalyst even if PDA can react with 2-CP without the catalyst compared with entries 4 and 5. Meanwhile, entry 6 and entry 7 proved that PDA cannot be fully converted without 2-CP, even with CO2. Therefore, these phenomena further demonstrate that PDA could preferentially react with 2-CP, even without CO2. Therefore, equation 6 was determined to occur in the system. Subsequently, PDC was formed through reactions 7 and 8, in which N, N'-(pentane-1,5-diyl)dipicolinamide reacted with DEC through two steps. Based on the above results, it can be concluded that the reaction path involves the formation of N, N'-(pentane-1,5-diyl)dipicolinamide from PDA and 2-CP and its further esterification with DEC to form PDC. To acquire the structure of the surface intermediate, CO2 and ethanol were introduced to the Zr0.05Ce catalyst at the evaluated temperature of 190°C. The in-situ DRIFTS spectra of ethanol and CO2 adsorbed on the Zr0.05Ce catalyst at 190°C is illustrated in Fig. 10 . The peaks at 1049 and 1113 cm−1 were derived from the C–O stretching modes of the bridged ethoxy and terminal ethoxy of ethanol, respectively. The IR band at 1153 cm−1 originated from the ethoxy on Zr because of the doping of Zr. The negative bands between 3650 and 3690 cm−1 were ascribed to the consumption of surface hydroxyl groups upon ethanol adsorption; this observation was reported by other studies [31,43]. It suggested that the H atom of the OH from ethanol could form an OH group by interacting with the unsaturated O2− on the catalyst surface. Further, it could react with the OH group to produce surface water. Moreover, three species were formed, including bicarbonate, monodentate carbonate, and bidentate carbonate, when CO2 was adsorbed on the surface of the Zr0.05Ce catalyst. The IR bands at 3619, 1369, and 1218 cm−1 were assigned to the bicarbonate. The formation of the bicarbonate was accompanied by the disappearance of the hydroxyl group, suggesting that the hydroxyl group reacted with CO2 to form the bicarbonate. Bidentate carbonate was formed through the interaction of an oxygen atom of CO2 with the oxygen vacancy of a cerium atom on the CeO2 surface, which was proven by the emergence of peaks at 1577 cm−1, 1290 cm−1, 1020 cm−1, and 855 cm−1 when CO2 was introduced. This observation reflects the presence of surface oxygen vacancy. Further, the monodentate carbonate featured at 1429 cm−1 and 1342 cm−1 was observed on the catalyst surface. It is proven that the bidentate carbonate plays a crucial role in the formation of DEC. The monoethyl carbonate can be formed by the interaction between terminal ethoxy and bidentate carbonate, which suggests that DEC could be formed over the Zr0.05Ce catalyst [31]. To confirm this, the interaction of ethanol with adsorbed CO2 on the Zr0.05Ce catalyst was studied, as shown in Fig. S8. The exposure of the adsorbed CO2 to ethanol leads to a decrease in the bidentate carbonate content at 855 and 1290 cm−1. Meanwhile, the peaks at 1475, 1558, and 1750 cm−1 were attributed to monoethyl carbonate species, which is an important intermediate in the direct synthesis of carbonate from CO2 [49,50]. Furthermore, the reaction was monitored in real-time by in-situ FTIR spectroscopy to provide an analysis of the reaction pathway by tracking the concentration of reactants, intermediates, and products under the reaction conditions. First, the spectra of the pure PDA, 2-CP, DEC, and PDC dissolved in ethanol were recorded to help recognize these characteristic peaks. As shown in Fig. S9, the IR signal of the carbonyl group derived from DEC at ∼1745 cm−1 is easily distinguished from that from PDC (∼1700 cm−1) [13]. First, the reaction was performed without 2-CP at 160°C, and the three-dimensional (3D) surface plot for the reaction is illustrated in Fig. S10. In the beginning, the temperature increased to the desired value in a short time; thus, the intensity of all IR spectra suddenly decreased. The entire spectra almost did not change when 2-CP was absent in the reaction system. DEC, PDC, and specifically intermediates were not observed, suggesting that 2-CP was necessary for the production of PDC. Fig. 11 a depicted the reaction profile with 2-CP to confirm the combination effect of the 2-CP and catalyst. Fig. 11b illustrates the 3D surface plot for the reaction between 1200 and 1800 cm−1. The IR signal at 781 cm−1 originated from the–N–H–of PDA, which decreased to zero within 3 h, indicating that the PDA was gradually consumed during the reaction. Meantime, the wavenumber at 1748 cm−1 and 1261 cm−1 belonging to the –C=O–and –C–O–bands of DEC, respectively, was observed. It was confirmed that the DEC was continuously generated from CO2 and ethanol with 2-CP. More importantly, the signal at 1650 cm−1 ascribed to amide from intermediate II significantly increased, and it decreased after 1 h, indicating that it acts as an intermediate for the synthesis of PDC. The PDC was continuously formed at the beginning, as indicated by the IR signal at 1694 cm−1. Notably, 2-CP plays a dual role in the synthesis of PDC: removing the water for the formation of DEC and promoting the conversion of PDA [47]. Additionally, to investigate the reaction between the PDA and 2-CP, CO2 was not purged into the reactor (Fig. S11). DEC was not generated in the reaction because of the lack of CO2, and the IR signal of PDC was not observed. Meanwhile, the IR signal at 1650 cm−1 of N, N'-(pentane-1,5-diyl)dipicolinamide emerged significantly, and no decline was observed, which is different from the observations presented in Fig. 11a. This confirmed that N, N'-(pentane-1,5-diyl)dipicolinamide is from the reaction between the PDA and 2-CP and can be converted to PDC in both CO2 and 2-CP. Based on the above experimental results, a possible mechanism regarding the role of CeO2 in the carbonylation of PDA with CO2 is suggested and presented in Scheme 2 . The total process includes three parts, i.e., the formation of DEC, dehydration using 2-CP, and formation of PDC. Cycle 1 illustrates the important role of oxygen vacancy in the activation of CO2. DEC was first formed from CO2 and ethanol over the Zr0.05Ce catalyst. Active bidentate carbonate was generated by CO2 and adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst with oxygen vacancy, which is the key intermediate in the formation of DEC. Meanwhile, ethanol was adsorbed on the neighboring acidic site to form alkoxide species [42]. Thereafter, the two species reacted to form monodentate carbonate species, which reacted with another alkoxide to generate DEC and regenerate oxygen vacancy. Finally, the catalyst was reduced by dehydration through the reaction with 2-CP, which was shown in cycle 2. It was noted that 2-PA was generated by the reaction of 2-CP with H2O produced in cycle 1 [51,52]. Subsequently, the formed 2-PA reacted with PDA to form N, N'-(pentane-1,5-diyl)dipicolinamide [48]. Finally, the DEC formed in cycle 1 reacted with N, N'-(pentane-1,5-diyl)dipicolinamide to generate PDC. 3.5 Recyclability of catalysts Generally, stability is an important factor for evaluating catalysts. After every use, the used catalyst was washed with ethanol several times to remove the residual compound for the subsequent reaction. Therefore, the reusability of Zr0.05Ce in the PDC synthesis was tested, and the results are illustrated in Fig. 12 . Notably, the activity slowly decreased after five uses, suggesting that the catalyst became stable, and the yield of PDC decreased to 29%. To determine the mechanism of the decline of the catalytic activity, the characterizations of XPS, TEM, and thermogravimetry (TG) were carried out for the spent catalyst. The aggregation was not observed from the TEM images (Fig. S12) after the reaction, and the size of the catalyst remained unchanged, indicating that the morphology did not change after the reaction. The XPS spectra of the fresh and used catalysts are illustrated in Fig. S13. It was observed from the Ce 3d core level that the relative abundances of Ce3+ decreased from 47% to 39%. It was estimated that trace amounts of organic residues were adsorbed on the catalyst surface and blocked the oxygen vacancy, which cannot be washed by ethanol. Additionally, three carbon species were observed on the surface of the catalyst: C–C species (284.8 eV), C–O–C species (286.16 eV), and O–C=O species (288.65 eV). The deconvolution of the C 1s spectra of the used catalyst showed that the concentrations of the C–O–C and O–C=O species were higher than those of the fresh catalyst, further demonstrating that the catalyst was contaminated with an organic compound. Further, some low IR signals ranging from 750–1750 cm−1 of the used catalyst appeared after the reaction, which were probably ascribed to the C=O, C–N, and C–H bonds, confirming that some species existed on the surface of the catalyst (Fig. S14). Next, TG analyses were carried out, and the result showed 4% of weight loss in the range of 50°C–800°C. (Fig. S15) Similar phenomena were previously observed [44,48]. Tamura et al. and Urakawa et al. explained that 2-CP was adsorbed over the defect site of CeO2 to form 2-PA-like species, which blocked the active sites and resulted in the decline in catalytic activity. It was confirmed that some substances from 2-CP were deposited on the catalyst surface and caused a decrease in catalytic performance. Notably, the catalytic activity was recovered after calcination at 550°C for 4 h, which suggests that the organic compound was hard to remove using ethanol and was easy to clear up at a high temperature. 4 Conclusions In this work, bio-based PDC was successfully synthesized via the carbonylation of PDA, CO2, and ethanol, which provided a sustainable and green route toward the carbonylation reaction for carbamates. Zr0.05Ce exhibited a remarkable catalytic performance for the production of PDC. Under the optimized reaction conditions, 100% of PDA conversion and 75.7% yield of PDC were achieved over the Zr0.05Ce catalyst from the direct carbonylation of PDA and CO2. In situ DRIFTS spectra confirm that CO2 reacts with ethanol to produce DEC, in which the oxygen vacancy from Zr0.05Ce plays a crucial role. Subsequently, PDA experiences the carbonylation reaction with DEC promoted by 2-CP to form PDC, where acidic and basic sites act as the main active sites. The active sites might be blocked by organic residues, which results in a decline in the catalytic activity after being used 5 times. Fortunately, the catalytic activity could be recovered after the catalyst was calcined. It is believed that this study can contribute to the literature on the synthesis of bio-based carbamate by a green and sustainable method. coredata.dc:description: Diethyl pentane-1,5-diyldicarbamate (PDC), a bio-based intermediate used for isocyanate and polyurethanes, was synthesized by the direct carbonylation of CO2 and pentanediamine (PDA) with 2-cyanopyridine (2-CP) over Zr-doped CeO2. In this study, Zr-doped CeO2 catalysts with different contents of Zr are successfully synthesized to produce PDC from PDA, CO2, and ethanol. Among them, Zr0.05Ce exhibits enhanced reaction activity and the productivity reached 6.0 mmol·g−1·h−1. Characterizations based on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Raman, and CO2/NH3-temperature-programmed desorption prove that the doping of Zr atoms into CeO2 regulates the acid–base sites and promotes oxygen vacancy formation, which is primarily responsible for the formation of monoethyl carbonate, an intermediate for diethyl carbonate (DEC). In-situ diffuse reflectance Fourier-transform spectrometry and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy reveal that PDA reacts with 2-CP to form N, N'-(pentane-1,5-diyl)dipicolinamide, which are transformed into PDC. Finally, the catalytic activity could be regenerated after calcination. This study presents a green route for producing bio-based carbamate by constructing C-N bond using CO2 as a carbonyl source, which can replace carbamates derived from petrochemical resources in the future.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of bio-based diethyl pentane-1,5-diyldicarbamate via the carbonylation of pentanediamine with CO2 over a zirconium-doped CeO2 catalyst
